summary: This is the Office of the Inspector General's report investigating the Federal Bureau of Prisons' custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York from his arrest on July 6, 2019, until his death by suicide on August 10, 2019. The report details numerous and serious failures by BOP staff, including falsification of records, failure to assign a cellmate, failure to conduct required rounds and counts, and allowing an unmonitored phone call, which created an environment where Epstein could take his own life. The OIG found no evidence contradicting the FBI's determination that his death was a suicide. This is the Office of the Inspector General's (OIG) official draft report on the Federal Bureau of Prisons' (BOP) care, custody, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It contains eight recommendations for BOP policy changes following Epstein's death, along with the BOP's responses and the OIG's analysis of those responses.

events.title: Epstein's Arrest
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey and transported to MCC New York on federal sex trafficking charges.

events.title: First Hanging Incident
events.description: Epstein found in his SHU cell with an orange cloth around his neck. Cellmate reported Epstein tried to hang himself. Epstein placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Cellmate Directive Issued
events.description: MCC New York Psychology Department emailed over 70 staff stating Epstein 'needs to be housed with an appropriate cellmate' following his removal from psychological observation.

events.title: Epstein Signs New Will
events.description: Epstein met with his attorneys at MCC New York and signed a new Last Will and Testament, unbeknownst to prison officials.

events.title: Cellmate Transferred, Documents Unsealed
events.description: Epstein's cellmate (Inmate 3) transferred out of MCC New York; no new cellmate assigned. Second Circuit unsealed ~2000 pages of documents in Ghislaine Maxwell civil litigation, generating extensive media coverage.

events.title: Unmonitored Phone Call
events.description: A Unit Manager allowed Epstein to make an unrecorded, unmonitored telephone call on a legal line, purportedly to his mother but actually to Individual 1.

events.title: Failure to Conduct Counts and Rounds
events.description: SHU staff failed to conduct the 4 p.m. and 10 p.m. inmate counts and rounds after ~10:40 p.m. Falsified records to indicate they were performed.
personsInvolved: Evening Watch SHU Officer in Charge

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: At approximately 6:30 a.m., SHU staff found Epstein hanged in his cell. He was pronounced dead at a hospital at 7:36 a.m. Autopsy later ruled death a suicide by hanging.

events.title: Security Camera System Failure
events.description: Disk failures occurred in the DVR 2 system of MCC New York's security cameras, causing approximately half the institution's cameras (including most in the SHU) to stop recording, though live feed continued. Not discovered until August 8.

keyFacts: The OIG found no evidence contradicting the FBI's determination that Epstein's death was a suicide and no evidence of criminality in how he died.
MCC New York staff failed to assign Epstein a new cellmate on August 9, 2019, after his cellmate was transferred, contrary to a Psychology Department directive issued on July 30.

SHU staff, including Tova Noel and Michael Thomas, falsified BOP records to show they conducted required inmate counts and 30-minute rounds on August 9-10 when they had not, leaving Epstein unmonitored for hours.
An MCC New York supervisor allowed Epstein to make an unrecorded, unmonitored telephone call on August 9, in violation of BOP policy.
A malfunction in the prison's security camera recording system from July 29 resulted in limited recorded video evidence from the SHU area for August 9-10, though live feeds were available.
The OIG report makes eight specific recommendations to the BOP to address systemic failures revealed by the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death.
The BOP concurred with all eight recommendations in its response, but the OIG found its response to Recommendation 2 (ensuring high-risk inmates have a cellmate) was 'not fully responsive.'
A key finding was that BOP employees failed to take steps to ensure Jeffrey Epstein continuously had a cellmate, despite Psychology Department personnel determining he needed one.
The report states the issues leading to Epstein's death were 'the result of employees failing to adhere to their duties, as opposed to a staffing shortage.'
The OIG requires the BOP to provide updates and documentation on implementing the recommendations within 90 days for the recommendations to be considered closed.
